node.text:
Indigenous people in Minnesota get arrested for protesting the Line 3 pipeline at Red Lake Treaty Camp. This land belongs to the Indigenous people and the Line 3 pipeline will have serious long term effects on the environment. #StopLine3 via @davenewworld_2 on Twitter

Line 3 Pipeline: Line 3 is a proposed pipeline expansion to bring nearly a million barrels of tar sands per day from Alberta, Canada to Superior, Wisconsin. It was proposed in 2014 by Enbridge, a Canadian pipeline company responsible for the largest inland oil spill in the US. Enbridge seeks to build a new pipeline corridor through untouched wetlands and the treaty territory of Anishinaabe peoples, through the Mississippi River headwaters to the shore of Lake Superior. 

All pipelines spill. Line 3 isn’t about safe transportation of a necessary product, it’s about expansion of a dying tar sands industry. Line 3 would contribute more to climate change than Minnesota’s entire economy. Minnesota’s own Department of Commerce found our local market does not need Line 3 oil. We need to decommission the old Line 3 and justly transition to a renewable, sustainable economy.  Line 3 would violate the treaty rights of Anishinaabe peoples and nations in its path — wild rice is a centerpiece of Anishinaabe culture, it grows in numerous watersheds Line 3 seeks to cross. It’s well-past time to end the legacy of theft from and destruction of indigenous peoples and territories. 

via @goldenwolf5601 on TikTok (Follow us on Twitter to learn more, check stories to see what is happening and how you can help spread this information)

node.text:
New York City alone throws 1.4 Billion pounds of textiles each year including clothing, belts and shoes. 85% of that ends up in the landfills! (According to the NYC Department of Environmental Conservation)

We partnered with FARFETCH on a new project called Past Life where we highlight how clothes have many lives, so we begin caring for their past and future lives. A project to divert clothes from landfills.

A solution besides consuming less paired with buying less and wearing your clothes for longer can be to donate a piece of clothing via FARFETCH Donate -  a donation program that is part of the broader Positively FARFETCH strategy. 

The items donated will then be redistributed for meaningful use, rather than adding to the abundance of clothing waste.

A project by:
@farfetch x @theslowfactory

Directed by @sophfei
DP @agustinabiasutto
Edited by @wonseungii
AC @_eileeny_
Gaffer @lorenzopacedop
Sound @brauliolin
Hair @skimdo
Makeup @ayatariqmua @toodbeauty
Location @arkhous_bk
Music @collisbrowne

Special thanks to: ❤️

Kimberly Drew @museummammy
Mecca James-Williams @meccajw
Babba Rivera @babba
Maria Alia Al-sadek @mariaalia
Fran Tirado @fransquishco
Céline Semaan @celinecelines
Sophia Li @sophfei

node.text: Haunani K. Trask was a powerful leader who fought for the freedom and justice of the Hawaiien people, affirming the Hawaiian culture, identity and politics by speaking truth to power. We hold her in our hearts as she transitions with the ancestors, and we continue the fight.

node.title: We mourn the loss of legendary Haunani K. Trask

node.text:
Biden is NO climate hero, the Biden administration is supporting the largest tar sand pipeline in the world and the most expensive one estimated at $9B harassing and arresting Indigenous women and groups water protectors violating the treaties and their illegal occupation of their land to build and create new routes through Indigenous territories for the most environmentally toxic and destructive project: Alberta’s Tar Sands.

Repost from @democracynow
•
Thousands gathered for a Treaty People Gathering weekend of action to #StopLine3, which would carry more than 750,000 barrels of tar sands oil a day through Indigenous land and fragile ecosystems and endanger lakes, rivers and wild rice beds. More than 100 water protectors led by Indigenous Anishinaabe women were arrested Monday in northern Minnesota during the largest act of civil disobedience to date to halt the pipeline, which if completed, would be "the largest tar sands pipeline in the world," says Winona LaDuke, an Anishinaabe activist and executive director of @honortheearth. "We have a Canadian corporation coming in here trying to make a buck at the end of the fossil fuels era and run over a bunch of Indigenous people, and we're not having it."

node.title: Biden administration supports Canadian Tar San Illegal Pipeline

Sounds of your childhood with @ty_ushka exploring climate justice migration and climate refugees through sound. #worldoceansday Sounds of the waves 🌊

Shout out to @culturestrike “Lead with culture not policy” ❤️

📻 I Really Love this Song is a conceptual digital exhibition and visual mixtape curated by @theslowfactory commissioning twenty artists who are in their own right leading voices contributing in the on-going revolution at the intersection of climate and human rights. Powered with @drinkruna official media partner with @dazed #IReallyLoveThisSong 🌈

First 100 to get their free passes will receive a special gift curated by us 👀 including: 🦺 Special collection available for I Really Love this Song is made in partnership with @versiontomorrow

node.text:
Elgorithm’s ( @elgorithm )
Trauma Relief Fund

As part of the 10 month remember since of the Beirut Explosion, as well as the launch of Elgorithm’a Trauma Relief Fund, we’ve prepared a video on Lebanon’s mental health crisis.

“On August 4th 2020 two explosions erupted in the port of Beirut, Lebanon, which sent shockwaves across the city and beyond — people felt the impact up to 150 miles away, with individuals in neighboring island Cyprus reporting noise and rattling windows.

Lebanese homes, businesses and full city blocks were destroyed while thousands were injured and needed immediate care. Hospitals, which were already overwhelmed due to rising Covid-19 cases, are dealing with mass casualties despite limited resources. According to Al Jazeera, three hospitals were fully destroyed while two were damaged. The death toll is currently at 137 and rising, and 5,000 have been injured.” wrote @celinecelines for @voguemagazine the days following the deadly explosion

The final count of people killed because of this explosion amounts to 207, 300,000 were left homeless, 7,500 were injured.

Prioritizing trauma relief is central in healing our bodies and spirits in order to heal our land and city. Please consider supporting @elgorithm fund for Beirut.

node.text:
📌 Reposting this live between @ahmedeldin and @celinecelines, now with ASL interpretation and captions as promised 🤟❤️
. . .
In this live, the two demystify Free Palestine as a movement anchored in human rights for all, a movement at the end to antisemitism. They answer the age-old question “but Hamas?” and define urbicide: the action of destroying entire cities (Gaza) and the role of the media in the manipulation of truth and censorship.

node.text:
Temporarily saving this Live with @ahmedeldin here on IGTV so we can download it and add close captions & include our ASL interpreters—In this Live @celinecelines & @ahmedeldin demystify Free Palestine as a movement anchored in human rights for all, a movement at the opposite end to Anti-Semitism. We answer the age-old question “but Hamas” and define urbicide: the action of destroying entire cities (Gaza). The role of the Media and the manipulation of truth, censorship. We will be adding subtitles / ASL

node.text:
Celebrating Earth Day with a partnership with @pinterest x @theslowfactory discussing Peer to peer knowledge — Open Education ✏️ and the power of visual learning and images. Check out our Boards on Pinterest 1) Earth Day Archive 2) Open Education where all of our visual information is available as an open archive for all 🌎

EDUCATION IS THE FOUNDATION OF PROGRESS

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Slow Factory 🌍 on August 03, 2021. May be an image of crustacean and text that says 'Slow Factory Foundation The Effects of Eviction on the Environment Climate injustice in Palestine Image Source Eva Bartlett'.

node.text:
🌿🐝🌏 Indigenous peoples are responsible for protecting 80% of the world’s biodiversity, so what happens when these people are expelled or restricted from their own land? 

In a conflict where land is so central, what are the effects of Isra*l’s illegal occupation of Palestinian land? 

🚱In Gaza alone, where the land and water are either completely restricted or at the least, overseen and controlled by Isra*l, 97% of water is undrinkable, and much of the soil has been devastated from the leftover residue of explosives. Not only the quality of water, but the division of water remains disproportionate as Isra*li settlers consume more than six times the amount of water that Palestinian residents in the West Bank do.
The water in the Jordan Valley is diverted and native trees and crops have been systematically uprooted to make way for European pines that restrict and harm native wildlife and cause forest fires. 

🌱Despite pollution, apartheid, mismanagement, and destruction to indigenous biodiversity, the main issue remains the unyielding seizure of land to create illegal settlements. In the past, Isra*l has even publicly presented areas such as Abu Ghuneim Mountain, Ras Imweis and its neighboring villages as “green areas' ' meant for preservation before converting them into the Har Homa and Nahal Shilo settlements 2-3 years later.  Palestinians are losing their homes, farms, and livelihoods in a dark tradition of stealing, colonizing, and exploiting land far too often.

🟩 Isra*l’s greenwashing campaigns are adamant, but no, they did not “make the desert bloom”.  They simply exercised imperial control of land, water, and resources, towards what indigenous Palestinians had been caring for and cultivating centuries prior. 

Sources: Worldwide Life, Al Jazeera , Science for the People, & Decolonize Palestine.  

ID: 

Slide 1: Olive green white white text that reads “The Effects of Eviction on the Environment. Climate Injustice in Palestine” Hands holding burnt wheat. Slow Factory Foundation Icon in top right corner.

ID continued in comments ✏

node.text:
🌞🎊 Ayyyyee! It’s almost that time again! We’ve partnered with @vestiaireco to bring you Open Edu Summer Camp 2021! 🏖🎉

💥We’re starting off with a real banger, The History of Fast Fashion: How did this system take over?, taught by Aja Barber @ajabarber. Aja, a writer, consultant, and stylist based in London, takes us on a journey through fast fashion, to look back at how we got here and where the heck we’re going. 

📌Join us this Friday, August 6, 2021 at 12 PM EDT. Still need to sign up? Don’t worry, the link is in our bio!

Take part in the conversation on Slack. Join us at our channel 📲 # summer-camp-fast-fashion

node.text:
Just like Covid-19, climate change will impact BIPOC communities more than anyone else.  It also shows us that we need to combine preventative and reparative action to address both of these problems. Bottom line - we need each other to get through this.

ID: illustration.  Grey concrete wall, speckled with black. In the center, a drawing in dark grey of a woman with dark, curly hair wearing a mask. She is looking off to the right. Text below reads : " Wearing a mask shoes community solidarity" In the bottom right corner lies the "S" icon for Slow Factory Foundation

node.text:
🌻🍄Alexis Nikole Nelson, known as @blackforager , untagles centuries of systemic oppression, racist policies like redlining, and erasure by taking it back to the root, to where it all begins and ends: the Earth. 

🌿Foraging is nothing new to Black folks, Indigenous peoples, or humans in general, but the very act of looking to the Earth for sustenance can, in itself, be a revolutionary one. 

⚖Laws in the postbellum south "closed the range", essentially prohibiting foraging for food on public lands. These laws were designed to directly impact newly freed Black folks, threatening their means of survival,  and often times, forcing them to return to the very plantations they'd just left. [Fordham Urban Law Journal]

The early 20th saw the migration of Black folks from the South, to Northern cities. As folks left, looking for better, some boldly stated that they would never look back, or till the land again. ✋🛑

🌱What happens when the "looking back" can finally happen? What grows there? 

Alexis believes that foraging can open up the possibilities of discovering new food sources, help us to uncover links to our heritage, and allow us care for each other in a fuller way (foraged foods have more nutrients than their grocery counterparts!) [University of Berkeley Food Institute]

ID:

Slide 1: Lush greenery. White Queen Anne's Lace flowers sprinkle the ground . A brown skin woman wearing a blue, ruffled, corseted top, and grey pants, stands amongst the bushes . She has brown glasses and a wide-brimmed, straw hat with a red satin ribbon tied around her chin. She holds pruning shears in one hand, while touching the branch in front of her with her other hand. She is looking towards camera with a sense of serenity. 

Slide 2: white background and black text . A shared tweet reads “What’s more integral to our lives & future than direct control over our immediate environment & living space? The air we breathe, water we drink, & food we eat…we need to learn to control these spaces we inhabit. We can no longer afford to allow others to do this for us.”

ID continued in comments ✏

What you should do What are you good at? (your special skills, network, resources, & magic) What is the work that needs doing? (climate & justice solutions)'.

node.text:
🎉🎊 We are teaming up with All We Can Save @allwecansave co-editors Dr. Ayana Elizabeth Johnson @ayanaeliza, marine biologist, and co-founder of @urbanoceanlab, and Dr. K Wilkinson @drkwilkinson, author, educator, and strategist, to offer our community the chance to win 5 copies of the paperback edition of the book! 📖 

🔀 Intermixing writings with poetry and art, AWCS is both a balm and a guide for knowing and holding what has been done to the world, while strengthening our purpose to never give up on each other or our collective future.

🌱 Building and nurturing community, compassion, and commitment to justice is vital if we are to address the climate crisis, and from this idea, AWCS Reading Circles grew. These circles are self-organized groups from all over, who commit to reading the anthology over the course of 10 sessions. These communities help to bring clarity to the role that we can play within the climate space. These Circles, the “connective tissue”, provide a space where folks can explore, dream, and take diverse action. 

To enter ➡️  In the comments, tell us who your dream reading circle partner would be!

👀 If you’re simply too excited, you can absolutely buy the book now! ⬆️⬆️Link in bio. 

Happy reading! We’re so excited to be on this journey to create a just future together. 🤝

💛 Art by @Madeleine_jubilee_saito

(climate & justice solutions)” In the left-most circle, sits a twinkle emoji, below, black text reads “What are you good at? (your special skills, network, resources, & magic)” In the top circle, an emoji of a small, budding plant sits a top black text that reads “ What brings you joy? (what gets you up in the morning? Neglecting your joy will lead to burnout.)

node.text:
Grab your sunglasses, our future is bright ! 😎

Registration for Open Edu Summer Camp 2021 is now OPEN!! ☀️🏖🍉

We’re bringing back some incredible classes guaranteed to spice up your summer. 
Open Edu is our open and equity-centered education initiative for Black, Brown, Indigenous and minority ethnic communities taught by Black, Brown, Indigenous and minority ethnic scholars, thinkers, and educators.

Education is the foundation of progress and Open Edu Summer Camp is all about teaching you what school won’t! We’ve proudly partnered with Vestiaire Collective (@vestiaireco) to bring you a month of classes focused on dismantling systems of oppression like fast fashion and disposable culture. Let’s do this together 🤝

👀 Swipe left to see the curriculum 

🤟 All Open Edu classes have ASL Interpretation and captions

🗓 Sign up today so that you can stay in the loop and bask in the peace of mind that you won’t miss a single thing! 

⬆️ ⬆️ Link in bio

📌 Don’t forget to join the Slow Factory Book Club 

📚 Find us on Slack at our # book-club channel 

ID:

Slide 1: white background and black text that reads “Open Edu Summer Camp” in top left corner, beside it, stands an illustration of a cheerful, yellow-red ombré Backpack with three legs and a smiling face. A small, 3D, yellow-red ombré box with a white, Slow Factory “S” lies in the background to the left. A small, black circle in the upper corner with white texts reads “what school won’t teach you”. Icon for ASL Interpretation in bottom right corner to indicate access for every Open Edu class. Black text in the bottom left corner are partnership logos for Slow Factory Foundation x Vestiaire Collective

ID continued in comments ✏

node.text:
How do your clothes make you feel? Powerful? Smart? Worthy? Beautiful? How can we sustain connection with the clothes we live in?

Past Life, a partnership with @FARFETCH, is a project to reflect and honor the past and future lives of our clothes.

🗑👚 Diverting clothes from landfills is the goal! But how?

Aside from buying less + wearing our clothes for longer (loved clothes last!), you can donate a piece of clothing via FARFETCH Donate! 

The items donated will be redistributed (+reloved!) for meaningful use, rather than adding to the plethora of clothing waste, and fueling toxic fast fashion culture. 

♥️ Special thanks to Kimbery Drew (@museummammy), author of "This is What I Know About Art", co-editor of "Black Futures", curator, and activist. 

Want to learn more about how we can dismantle colonial systems of oppression like disposable culture and fast fashion? You’re in luck! Sign up for Open Edu Summer Camp, where we will bring a month full of classes to inspire us to change our world for the better. 🌍🌎🌏 

⬆️ Link in Bio

🤟 all Open Edu classes are available with ASL Interpreters and captions

ID: 
Video of a dark skin woman with short black hair, in a lime green dress, blue hoop earrings, a long string of pearls holding up a grey dress. She is standing in front of a grey wall and window. Video cuts to close ups of her face with a blue light, also cuts to close ups of the grey dress and pearls.

node.text:
Sustainability is a Culture ♻️💚 

Cultures of the Global Majority have been exercising slow approaches to climate justice and sustainable fashion for centuries. 

We believe that people of the Global Majority have a more holistic approach to sustainability as a cultural norm. 

We naturally extend the life of every single object that enters our households. Often, this is based on necessity, but also on traditional knowledge where disposability is not the default. 

Adopting a capitalistic approach towards fashion is warped. We operate at high speeds, consuming and discarding in an endless cycle. What would happen if we viewed our clothing with love? Care? Respect? How can our clothes be honored in their future lives? 

Join us for Open Edu Summer Camp ( 🤝w/ @vestiaireco ) as we explore why Fast Fashion is still out here extracting resources and outputting waste. How did we get here? How do we design a way out and around it? 

Original tweet by @emmy_zo_
Reposted by @yaaasssmeen ♥️

ID:

White background, black text. A tweet shared that reads "In my country people don't throw out any clothes. When the outfit starts fading , it becomes your home outfits then sleeping outfits then when it's all tattered you'll find mom dusting the furniture with it"

node.text:
Welcome to Open Edu Summer Camp 2021! ☀️🏖🍉
We’re so excited to share our August 2021 curriculum, featuring some absolutely astounding educators ✏ 

Open Edu is our open and equity-centered education initiative for Black, Brown, Indigenous and minority ethnic communities taught by Black, Brown, Indigenous and minority ethnic scholars, thinkers, and educators ♥️ 

We couldn’t be happier to say that Open Edu Summer Camp is FREE! Sign up for our newsletter and you’ll be in the loop about how to register for classes so you’ll never have to worry about missing anything.🗓 Link in bio ⬆️ ⬆️ 

Education is the foundation of progress, and Open Edu Summer Camp is all about teaching you what school won’t! As part of Vestiaire Collective (@vestiaireco) #Collectiveforchange, they’ve partnered with us to bring you a month of classes focused on the disposable culture of fast fashion. As students of life and critical thinkers, let's continue evolving and working to dismantle colonial systems of oppression 🤝 

Swipe to see the curriculum 👀 

🤘all classes will have ASL interpretation 

ID: 

Slide 1: white background and black text that reads “Open Edu Summer Camp” A bouncy , non-binary, yellow-red ombré figure is walking.  A small, black circle in the upper right-hand corner with white text reads “what school won’t teach you” . Icon for ASL Interpretation in bottom right corner to indicate access for every Open Edu class. Black text in the bottom left corner are partnership logos for Slow Factory Foundation x Vestiaire Collective 

Slide 2: graphic with white background and black text that reads “ Open Edu Summer Camp” in top left corner, beside it, an illustration of an orange/red staircase and polka-dotted squiggle in the background. Below,  the syllabus in b: “  Aug 6 - The History of Fast Fashion: How did this system take over? - Aja Barber/ Aug 13 - The Culture of Disposability: How did we make throwing good things away part of our culture? - Céline Semaan / Aug 20 - The History of Resale Markets: Throwing away clothes for a living - Liz Ricketts / Aug 27 - Open Edu Live Session: Town Hall Q&A - Ask Us Anything!” ID continued in comments ✏

node.text:
We believe that education is the foundation of progress and the first step in creating radical collective change. 

Though we know that these oppressive systems capitalize on what we popularize, we want to take a moment to remind you of what these systems and leaders fear the most…. 

LOVE AND IDEAS. 

Love frees us, and ideas allow us to truly imagine a possible future. A different future. 

So before this lends itself to marketing and greenwashing schemes, remember your power. Practice love and don’t be afraid of your big ideas!! 

Stay tuned for an exciting Open Edu announcement coming up!
@celinecelines @lov3ronica 🤟

node.text:
Indigenous people in Minnesota get arrested for protesting the Line 3 pipeline at Red Lake Treaty Camp. This land belongs to the Indigenous people and the Line 3 pipeline will have serious long term effects on the environment. #StopLine3 via @davenewworld_2 on Twitter

Line 3 Pipeline: Line 3 is a proposed pipeline expansion to bring nearly a million barrels of tar sands per day from Alberta, Canada to Superior, Wisconsin. It was proposed in 2014 by Enbridge, a Canadian pipeline company responsible for the largest inland oil spill in the US. Enbridge seeks to build a new pipeline corridor through untouched wetlands and the treaty territory of Anishinaabe peoples, through the Mississippi River headwaters to the shore of Lake Superior. 

All pipelines spill. Line 3 isn’t about safe transportation of a necessary product, it’s about expansion of a dying tar sands industry. Line 3 would contribute more to climate change than Minnesota’s entire economy. Minnesota’s own Department of Commerce found our local market does not need Line 3 oil. We need to decommission the old Line 3 and justly transition to a renewable, sustainable economy.  Line 3 would violate the treaty rights of Anishinaabe peoples and nations in its path — wild rice is a centerpiece of Anishinaabe culture, it grows in numerous watersheds Line 3 seeks to cross. It’s well-past time to end the legacy of theft from and destruction of indigenous peoples and territories. 

via @goldenwolf5601 on TikTok (Follow us on Twitter to learn more, check stories to see what is happening and how you can help spread this information)

node.text:
#repost to include all slides:

Both climate refugees and internal climate migrants refer to peoples who are displaced from their homes due to natural disasters and extreme environmental circumstances. 

In both cases, the countries and populations that are most severely affected are those least equipped to handle the effects of climate change. On average, these countries take in more than 90% of refugees and 70% of internally displaced people. 

This is an ongoing, daily, disaster, that is more than just an environmental issue. As climate change, conflict, and political and economic tension are inextricably connected, this is a human rights issue. 🌍 

🤝 We CAN curtail this crisis by focusing on prevention & actionable solutions.

Biden’s executive order for his administration to analyze, offer foreign aid, and devise solutions for the protection and resettlement of those affected & displaced due to climate change is a pivotal step in the right direction. 

Countries across the world are responsible to take similar steps so that those who are displaced can garner protection and support under international law. 

As always, preventative actions are most effective, so we’re calling for corporations, companies & governments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and consider climate migration in their development plans.

Promoting awareness and using clear and concise language to describe this growing and vulnerable population are essential to mitigate this crisis. ✊🏻✊🏼✊🏽✊🏾✊🏿

ID: 
Slide 1: Slow Factory definition card that reads: The term “climate refugee” refers to those who are forcibly displaced by natural disasters and other environmental catastrophes and must seek shelter and livelihood in other countries. Currently, climate refugees are not protected under international law, as the 1951 Refugee Convention does not recognize climate refugees as an at-risk population. Source: climaterefugees.org

✏️ continues in comments ⬇️
